/COMMIT_MSG.message:
As an alternative to this, how about we change the getNodeRequest method in zk/nodepool.py to accept nodeset=None, and in that case, construct a new nodeset object from the the nodes attribute.

That seems like it will produce more explicit code, so we don't have to have an AnonymousNodeSet class which performs implicit operations.

Which nodes attribute do you mean? The "node_types" are only created for the the serialization to ZK based on the request.nodeset attribute (https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/model.py#L871) but never retrieved from it.

But maybe I can put this logic directly in the updateNodeRequest() method and iterate over data["node_types"] in case node_request.nodeset is not set:  https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/799833/1/zuul/zk/nodepool.py#b483

zuul/scheduler.py.message: I think it's okay to do this in one change.

Is it a problem for the frontend if we completely remove the result_event_queue from the status JSON? If so, we could set the queue length to 0 first, adapt the frontend and remove the result_event_queue key in a follow-up change.
So let's update this to also remove the usage of it.
Does this do something meaningful if we return a dummy nodeset?

Yes, the "dummy" nodeset is perhaps a misnomer -- at this point it's a real nodeset, it's just one that's been re-constituted from ZK.  It has all of the real node information in it and therefore can be returned.

zuul/zk/nodepool.py.message: Is there any issue with these names potentially colliding with real node names on a fresh nodepool install?

Nope -- the name is unused, it's not even stored in ZK.  It's the name we give to Ansible (e.g. "controller").  We could supply the empty string here if we wanted.

Note that in just a few lines, these nodes will be fully populated from ZK data and then can be acted on in the normal way.

Maybe dummy nodeset is the wrong name here, but I didn't came up with something better. I wanted to emphasize that the nodeset itself is not built from "real" data (meaning it's not built from the job's nodeset config), but I don't know if that has any impact. The nodes however, do contain the real Nodepool data after being updated from ZK. But if I'm not mistaken there are also attributes like name and label which might be different from the "real" data (again, "real" meaning the data in the job configuration).

This helps a bunch, thanks. My only thought here is that we might be better off setting name to something that indicates the unused nature of the value. For example f"unused-{node_type}-{i}" or similar.

I didn't get your point here. Can you please explain me a little more?
or is this follow the same implementation just like in L949

This decorator is @mock.patch.object(). With this, you are mocking shell_v2 and _find_share_group from the original class. I understand that you are trying to pass share_group_to_delete as a param and instantiate with ddt. In that case, @ddt decorator is the one you need.
No need to mock this object here if we mock it on L2748

Change this line for "@mock.patch.object(shell_v2, '_find_share_group', mock.Mock())"

Add, just above or below, the line "@ddt.data(('share_group_xyz', ), ('share_group_abc', 'share_group_xyz'))"

Add the @ddt decorator here, with the values for share_group_to_delete, as you did in your previous patch set. You will have one decorator on top of the other (@ddt in one line, @mock.patch.object in the second line)

If you inspect the logs for py3X gate, you will see this output:

"TypeError: test_share_group_delete_wait() missing 1 required positional argument: 'share_group_to_delete'"

> pep8: H306: imports not in alphabetical order (manilaclient.v2.share_types, manilaclient.v2.share_groups)

Put this line after L38. Imports should be in alphabetical order.

This can't be a string, it has to be a callable. 
This is because this resolves to the Share Group resource's "manager" attribute/object [1], and the delete call is actually being resolved with this manager [2]

You can create a fake manager and use it as follows:

  fake_manager = mock.Mock()
  fake_share_group = [
            share_groups.ShareGroup(fake_manager, {'id': share_group})
            for share_group in share_groups_to_delete
  ]
 
[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-manilaclient/blob/80ec2919ca6dafe458c2db2e455f937e2f67cfe2/manilaclient/common/apiclient/base.py#L435
[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-manilaclient/blob/a68aaab1723b209de8d314abc7192d373074825a/manilaclient/v2/share_groups.py#L41-L43

Since we're mocking out the client manager, we can't assert the exact API call

The lines you commented out L2775 to L2780 should be used instead. With that, we can check the mocked manager was invoked correctly.

So, remove L2774 to L2776, and comment out L2777 to L2780

We are calling with the flag force=False, so you would need to change this to read like

 fake_manager.delete.assert_has_calls([
            mock.call(share_group,
                      force=False) for share_group in fake_share_group])

This test needs to fixed too, since it's using the same call.

Following the same style for the last test, we can do something like this

    def test_share_group_delete_force(self):
        fake_manager = mock.Mock()

zuul.d/upgrades-jobs-templates.yaml.message:
we should run -wallaby if this template runs on master (we upgrade here from victoria to wallaby, right?)
in case it will run on wallaby and not on master, then we need below just "..-oooq-container-updates" not "-oooq-container-updates-wallaby"
Or where is it supposed to run?

this content provider *is* wallaby so we have one for W and one for V, correct for the undercloud upgrade we go from victoria to wallaby.

We *could* make is content-provider-wallaby and content-provider-victoria in this template. But  then we would end up running one extra content provider (the situation we used to have).

Consider this example zuul result https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/799552/1#message-9a28451afef125970ce3e3f05c3d1378d99affc1 
It is for stable/victoria. You can see we have content-provider and content-provider-ussuri. We don't have the explicit -victoria one there.

This is because the content-provider in that case is running for -victoria branch already for tripleo-heat-templates. So e.g. the scen1 standalone and all other jobs there are using the content-provider. 

If we make this template declare explicitly -victoria and -wallaby it will work fine. But when we wire it up e.g. in tripleo-heat-templates, we would end up with 3 content providers:

content-provider (from other templates, like scenario/standalone jobs)
content-provider-wallaby, content-provider-victoria (from this template if we change it)

where the content-provider and content-provider-wallaby will be building the same thing (when this is a wallaby branch).

libvirt/values.yaml.message:
These values are way too aggressive IMO. The exec overhead of these probes is likely too much to only wait 1 second, I would up to at least 5 for the timeout.

Running every 10 seconds seems a bit much as well, once a minute may be better.

The delay should also be bumped up imo.

Generally speaking I loath having any probes run so frequently anyway and timeout so quickly, I mean, we don't set API or gateway timeout this short right?  If there is an opportunity to back this off some, I am all for it, although I am not exactly pushing for it, but if the opportunity presents itself such as now....

The value Gage suggests works for me, but probably appropriate to add some delay to liveness probe, maybe half of the frequency of the readiness, so 30s?

The default values per kubernetes spec are likely fine for a simple web service, but for libvirt here the computational overhead of exec'ing in and running virsh list is much higher than a simple HTTP probe.

We want the defaults in this chart to match the use case here.

30s is probably fine for the delay.

These are the default values per K8s pod.spec. The original intent was simply refactor the charts to enable overriding the probes without altering the functionality or behavior. If the default values are considered aggressive, it can be adjusted accordingly per deployment specific requirements.

This actually changes the default behaviour in order not to reserve the network and broadcast addresses anymore. While I think that that is a good idea in general, it needs to be documented properly, tested and mentioned in a release note.

This is related only to allocation pools. If the subnet is called with --subnet-range (cidr is manually assigned), the ml2 plugin "create_subnet" method will call "_validate_subnet". There the request will be rejected because "ip_ver == 4 and subnet_prefixlen > 30" is not allowed. Error message: "Subnet has a prefix length that is incompatible with DHCP service enabled"

Apart from handling this code path, you also need to consider checking if DHCP is enabled. We can't create a 3rd IP (for DHCP) in a /31 subnet.
In Bug case creating subnet with netmask /31 via disabling dhcp and gateway on a subnet. Why should we check again for dhcp?

I'm not sure how I feel about this feature now that we can do it through the "cinder create" flow.

We can currently do it if we use:

  cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.47 create --volume-type <vol-type> --availability-zone <az> <size>

So adding this new API makes it possible that we can have a bug in one of the flows and not the other...

I was discussing with Alan Bishop the possibility of adding the   command to the client, so when we use the right microversion we can use volume-type and availability-zone parameters and it's the client that changes the API endpoint it uses.  So for earlier versions we go through the backup API, and for newer versions we go through the create volume API.

A bus isn't a model though. Would it make sense to make this more generic, e.g. 'image-meta-list'? We could return all known embedded image metadata properties but only allow updating of whitelisted keys (namely, what you listed above plus hw_machine_type)

I'd also rather not deprecate the machine type commands as there's specific logic in there for handling migrations between versions and types etc that I'd rather not move.

specs/xena/approved/nova-manage-commands.message: I know this is a bit tangential. Do we have a good reason to stash the connection info in nova? Why don't we always ask the cinder, the source of truth, about the connection info?
thanks for the explanation.

I think it was stashed historically as the cinderv2 flow only allowed you to map (initialize_connection) and unmap (terminate_connection) there was no way of just GET'ing the connection again. It's also an obvious optimisation to avoid reaching out to Cinder during instance or host restarts.

Given the cinderv3 flow and our ability to GET an attachment and the stored connection_info I'd like to move away from stashing connection_info in the future but it's never got enough traction as it would have to happen atomically across all flows within the codebase at once.

Anyway as you say this is tangential as regardless of what we should be doing with connection_info it's stashed at present.
Good question. I personally don't know enough about this to say either.
Because I'm dumb, could you expand on why these steps are necessary versus nova updating the information itself as part of the 'start' action?

That would be tricky unless we did it directly in the libvirt virt driver. Basically today power_on calls _hard_reboot that disconnect and then reconnects the volume to the compute using the stashed connection_info. The compute layer can't update the connection_info prior to the libvirt driver calling disconnect so we'd have to do that directly in the driver. It's possible but wouldn't be a universal behaviour across the virt drivers at that point.

We've spoken at length about introducing some form of repair API in the past that could do stuff like this in the compute layer with multiple virt driver calls to cleanup and remount volumes etc.
nit:user's

Again a bit tangential but I think the operators doesn't really want a check and update operations, they want simply that: I as an operator want that nova always use an up-to-date connection info whenever it needs to do something with the given block device.

Sure if nova cannot provide that then a check and update nova-manage command still useful.

I can reiterate above some more but this spec isn't really for >= Xena it's for providing tooling to existing deployments where we can't rework how connection_info is used. What you're talking about with regards to connection_info isn't a simple thing and isn't something that's going to land in Xena, while stale connection_info and an inability to even see what connection_info Nova has is something operators are facing today.

I can write up a backlog spec detailing what I think would be required for us to move away from stashing connection_info but that shouldn't hold up this tooling IMHO.

I assume the point you're making is that adding the ability to refresh this info isn't the goal here. The goal here is to ensure the information is never out-of-date and we're simply choosing this mechanism to achieve that?

So I need to tighten up the language here a little. We should precreate an empty volume attachment without a connector before calling remove_volume_connection to ensure the volume remains `reserved`. We can't precate a volume attachment with a connector because of the existing attachment using the same connector.

We can't just GET the attachment to update the connection_info as that doesn't actually force a remapping of the volume to the compute by c-vol and the storage backend ensuring a full refresh. For that we need to tear down the existing attachment and then create.

diskimage_builder/elements/growvols/READ.message: Should there be a switch to disable this behaviour? i.e if the space is underallocated, then leave the unused LVM extents free, so that they can be used for new LV's later, or to grow an existing LV? (This can be implemented as a feature later.)

For now I wanted predictable idempotency behavior when the tool is run multiple times. 
Imagine a /=50% setting. On the first run it consumes 50%, on the second it consumes 50% of the remaining (25%) etc.

The easiest way to avoid this issue is to always consume 100% of space on the first run, just like growpart does.

If a use-case comes up to handle partial growing then I'm fine with adding it, we'll just need to be careful about how it behaves.
